bioghist.p: Augustus Köllner (1813-1900) was a lithographer, engraver, and landscape painter in watercolor. He was born in Germany and came to the United States in 1839 or 1840. He settled in Philadelphia and soon became associated with the lithographic firm of W. M. Huddy and Peter S. Duval. In 1851 he became a partner for a brief period of Henry Camp. He also made a series of lithographs for the American Sunday School Union. The earliest of these seems to have been produced in the late 1840s, with others following periodically in the 1850s. One of Köllner's favorite subjects was domestic animals.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of watercolors, drawings, etchings, lithographs, American Sunday School prints, and panoramas. Prints depict views of the Schuylkill and Delaware Rivers, Cobb's, Cohocksink, and Pennypack Creeks, Delaware Narrows, Fairmount Park, and bridges, houses, city street scenes, and charitable institutions. Other prints and drawings include a small number of views from outside of Pennsylvania, military uniforms (for U.S. Military Magazine), domestic animals, and lithographs produced for the American Sunday School Union.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
